citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
A 4 year old male cavalier king charles (microchip #900215000964754) had conjunctivitis in both eyes. The licensee had
not observed this prior to the inspection.
Conjunctivitis is a sign the dog may have an underlying health issue that may be contagious to other dogs and needs to
be treated by the Attending Veterinarian. Not observing the conjunctivitis in a timely manner and reporting it to the
Attending Veterinarian doesn't allow for the Attending Veterinarian to be able to properly diagnose and treat the dog
accordingly.
The dog must be treated by the Attending Veterinarian. Going forward, the licensee must provide daily observation to all
animals to ensure the health and well-being of the dogs.
Correct starting on 11/19/24.

APHIS Forms 7005 and 7006 were incomplete. 56 adult dogs were missing where they came from and the date of births
were also missing for these dogs. None of the dogs have the date acquired. Many of the 7006 records are missing the
disposition date.
Not having the 7005 and 7006 forms completely filled out doesn't allow for APHIS officials to be able to track the dogs
through the kennel.
APHIS forms 7005 and 7006 need to be completely filled out going forward. All known missing information needs to be
added to these forms and the forms should be made available to the APHIS inspector at the next inspection.
Correct starting on 12/19/24.

The program of veterinary care doesn't have anything in it for the sampling of dogs for the various fecal parasites or for
heartworm. The licensee is also not currently sampling the adult dogs for the various fecal parasites.
Not having a sampling schedule approved by the Attending Veterinarian and not sampling the adult dogs for fecal
parasites doesn't ensure the dogs are adequately protected from various diseases and parasites.
The Attending Veterinarian must add a sampling schedule to the program of veterinary care and all adult dogs must be
sampled for parasites in accordance with the plan from the Attending Veterinarian. Correct by 12/19/24.

The licensee is not currently documenting any of the distemper/parvo vaccinations for any of the adult dogs. Not having
documentation of all vaccines for all dogs doesn't ensure that the dogs are adequately protected from the diseases that
the vaccine is supposed to protect against. The licensee must accurately document all vaccines given to all dogs in a
timely manner moving forward. Correct starting on 11/19/24.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
End of report.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(3) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
A 4 year old male cavalier king charles (microchip #900215000964754) had conjunctivitis in both eyes. The licensee had 
not observed this prior to the inspection. 
 
Conjunctivitis is a sign the dog may have an underlying health issue that may be contagious to other dogs and needs to 
be treated by the Attending Veterinarian. Not observing the conjunctivitis in a timely manner and reporting it to the 
Attending Veterinarian doesn't allow for the Attending Veterinarian to be able to properly diagnose and treat the dog 
accordingly. 
 
The dog must be treated by the Attending Veterinarian. Going forward, the licensee must provide daily observation to all 
animals to ensure the health and well-being of the dogs. 
 
Correct starting on 11/19/24. 
2.75(a)(1) 
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
APHIS Forms 7005 and 7006 were incomplete. 56 adult dogs were missing where they came from and the date of births 
were also missing for these dogs. None of the dogs have the date acquired. Many of the 7006 records are missing the 
disposition date. 
 
Not having the 7005 and 7006 forms completely filled out doesn't allow for APHIS officials to be able to track the dogs 
through the kennel. 
 
APHIS forms 7005 and 7006 need to be completely filled out going forward. All known missing information needs to be 
added to these forms and the forms should be made available to the APHIS inspector at the next inspection. 
 
Correct starting on 12/19/24. 
3.13(a)(3)

Veterinary care for dogs. 
The program of veterinary care doesn't have anything in it for the sampling of dogs for the various fecal parasites or for 
heartworm. The licensee is also not currently sampling the adult dogs for the various fecal parasites. 
 
Not having a sampling schedule approved by the Attending Veterinarian and not sampling the adult dogs for fecal 
parasites doesn't ensure the dogs are adequately protected from various diseases and parasites. 
 
The Attending Veterinarian must add a sampling schedule to the program of veterinary care and all adult dogs must be 
sampled for parasites in accordance with the plan from the Attending Veterinarian. Correct by 12/19/24. 
3.13(b)(3) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
The licensee is not currently documenting any of the distemper/parvo vaccinations for any of the adult dogs. Not having 
documentation of all vaccines for all dogs doesn't ensure that the dogs are adequately protected from the diseases that 
the vaccine is supposed to protect against. The licensee must accurately document all vaccines given to all dogs in a 
timely manner moving forward. Correct starting on 11/19/24. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee. 
 
End of report. 
 
 n
